c74object.name: fluid.bufmelbands~
c74object.digest: A Perceptually Spread Spectral Contour Descriptor on a Buffer
c74object.discussion:
Open the Overview Patch
The spread is based on the Mel scale (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_scale) which is one of the first attempt to mimic pitch perception scientifically. This implementation allows to select the range and number of bands dynamically.
The process will return a single multichannel buffer of numBands per input channel. Each frame represents a value, which is every hopSize.
fluid.bufmelbands~ is part of the Fluid Decomposition Toolkit of the FluCoMa project. For more explanations, learning material, and discussions on its musicianly uses, visit flucoma.org.

FFT settings consist of three numbers representing the window size, hop size and FFT size in samples:
The hop size and fft size can both be set to -1 (and are by default), with slightly different meanings:

ul.li: For the FFT size, -1 = windowSize snapped to the nearest equal / greater power of 2 (e.g. windowSize 1024 => fftSize 1024, but windowsSize 1000 also => fftSize 1024)
FFTSize, if != -1, will set to the next greatest power of two > 4
The maximum manual FFT size is limited to the value of the maxfftsize initialization argument
if FFT size != -1, then window size is clipped at FFT size

How many frames should be processed.

Controls the zero-padding added to either end of the source buffer or segment. Possible values are 0 (no padding), 1 (default, half the window size), or 2 (window size - hop size). Padding ensures that all input samples are completely analysed: with no padding, the first analysis window starts at time 0, and the samples at either end will be tapered by the STFT windowing function. Mode 1 has the effect of centering the first sample in the analysis window and ensuring that the very start and end of the segment are accounted for in the analysis. Mode 2 can be useful when the overlap factor (window size / hop size) is greater than 2, to ensure that the input samples at either end of the segment are covered by the same number of analysis frames as the rest of the analysed material.
